questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of vaginal discharge and itching for 1 week. Upon examination, a profuse, thin, frothy yellow-green discharge and a strawberry cervix are noted. Which of the following statements regarding the causative organism is NOT true?

options.A: Flagellated trophozoite is the infective form.
options.B: It has a characteristic twitching motility.
options.C: It has one anterior and 4 posterior flagella.

questions.explanation: cervix, describes a case of Trichomoniasis, with 4 anterior flagella and 1 lateral flagellum (5 flagella) . Trichomoniasis: It is the most common parasitic sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by a flagellated parasite, Trichomonas vaginalis. It has only the trophozoite stage; there is no cyst stage. Trophozoite has two forms: Flagellated trophozoite : Infective and diagnostic form (Option A). Amoeboid trophozoite : Actively replicating form (found in the tissue feeding stage). Trophozoite of Trichomonas vaginalis It is a pear-shaped organism. It shows characteristic jerky or twitching motility in saline mount preparation (Option B) . It bears five flagella—four anterior flagella and one lateral flagellum called as recurrent flagellum. It has a single nucleus containing a central karyosome (Option D). Trophozoite Feature Trichomonas vaginalis Giardia lamblia Shape Pear-shaped or ovoid Heart-shaped or pyriform (tennis racket-shaped) Size 10-30 µm in length, 5-10 µm in breadth 15 µm long, 9 µm wide, 4 µm thick Flagella Five flagella- Four anterior flagella and one along the undulating membrane Four pairs of flagella arising from the blepharoplast Axostyle Prominent, runs the full length and projects posteriorly like a tail One axostyle running along the midline Cytoplasm Contains prominent siderophilic granules along the axostyle and costa It has two parabasal bodies Movement Rapid, jerky, or twitching motion Slow oscillation resembling a "falling leaf" movement Other Structures Undulating membrane which reaches up to the middle of the body Concave sucking disk on the ventral side for attachment to mucosa Images

Reservoir Hosts: T. brucei rhodesiense is often associated with wild and domestic animals serving as reservoir hosts, while T. brucei gambiense is primarily human-centric. questions.question: A 28-year-old male returns to his rural village after spending time in a forested area known for sandfly infestations. He presents to the clinic with a painless ulcer on his forearm that has gradually increased in size over the past month, as shown in the image below. The ulcer has raised, indurated borders and a necrotic base. The patient has no fever or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: sandflies. It typically presents as one or more painless ulcers with raised borders and a necrotic base, often referred to as "kala-azar ulcers." In this scenario, the patient's painless ulcer on the forearm aligns perfectly with the clinical presentation of cutaneous leishmaniasis. Cutaneous leishmaniasis: Most commonly caused by L.Tropica. Mode of transmission: The most common mode of infection is through the bite of sandflies. Infection may be transmitted from man to man or animal to man by direct inoculation or amastigotes. Incubation period: The incubation period varies from 2 to 8 months. Pathology: Amastigote forms are found in histiocytes and endothelial cells. There is an inflammatory granulomatous reaction with infiltration of lymphocyte and plasma cells. Early lesions are papular, followed by ulceration necrosis. Papules and ulcers are the main pathological lesions. They heal over months to years, leaving scars. Clinical features: L. tropica causes old-world cutaneous leishmaniasis. Three distinct patterns of old-world CL have been recognised. The anthroponotic urban type : Causing painless dry ulcerating lesions, leading to disfiguring scars. The most important vector is P. sergenti. - It is seen mainly in children in endemic areas and is called as oriental sore or Delhi boil. questions.question: A 30-year-old female, previously treated for visceral leishmaniasis six months ago, now presents with multiple erythematous, hypopigmented, slightly scaly papules and plaques on her face, neck, and arms. The lesions are painless, gradually increasing in number, and there are no associated systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: successful treatment of visceral leishmaniasis, characterized by the appearance of skin lesions, typically several months to years post-treatment. The lesions often present as hypopigmented macules, papules, or plaques, primarily on exposed areas of the body. Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis is a non ulcerative lesion of the skin seen in India, Nepal, Bangladesh and Sudan. The lesions are of three types: Depigmented or hypopigmented macules : These commonly appear on the face, the trunk and extremities and resemble tuberculoid leprosy. Erythematous patches : These are distributed on the face in a "butterfly distribution." Nodular lesion : Both of the earlier mentioned lesions may develop into painless yellowish-pink non-ulcerating granulomatous nodules. Diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis: The nodular lesions are biopsied, and amastigote forms are demonstrated in stained sections. The biopsy material can be cultured, or animal inoculation can be done. Immunodiagnosis has no role in the diagnosis of PKDL. Treatment of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis: Liposomal amphotericin-8 (AmBisome) 2.5 mg/ kg/ day for 20 days or sodium stibogluconate (SSG) 20 mg/ kg/day for 40- 60 days is given. questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with a 2-week history of fever, abdominal distension, fatigue, and significant weight loss. A rapid diagnostic test using the rK39 dipstick comes back positive. What is the recommended first-line drug for treating this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation: Treatment for Kala-azar: Pentavalent antimonial compound: Two pentavalent antimonial preparations are available: Sodium stibogluconate (100 mg of Sbv/mL) (SSG) Meglumine antimoniate (85 mg of Sbv/mL). Dosage: The daily dose is 20 mg/ kg by rapid intravenous (TV) infusion or intramuscular (IM) injection for 20- 30 days. Amphotericin-B : It is currently used as a first-line drug in Bihar. ln other parts of the world, it is used when initial antimonial treatment fails. Dosage: 0.75-1.0 mg/ kg on alternate days for a total of 15 infusions. Note: Fever with chills is almost seen in all patients, using amphotericin-8 infusions. Liposomal amphotericin-B (AmBisome) : It has been developed and used extensively to treat VL in all parts of the world. It is the only drug approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for the treatment of VL. Dose being 3 mg/ kg daily. By using liposomal amphotericin-B, higher doses can be given, improving the cure, without toxicity. Current recommendation in India is 10 mg/ kg single dose. Paromomycin : Paromomycin is an intramuscular aminoglycoside antibiotic with antileishmanial activity. Dosage: It is given in a dose of 11 mg/ kg daily for 21 days. Miltefosine : It is the first oral drug approved for the treatment of leishmaniasis. Dosage: 50 mg daily for 28 days for patients weighing less than 25 kg, and twice daily for patients weighing more than 25 kg. Prophylaxis : Early detection and treatment of all cases. Integrated insecticidal spraying to reduce sandfly population. Destruction of animal reservoir host in cases or zoonotic kala-azar. Regime of coadministered drug include: AmBisome + Paromomycin AmBisome + Miltefosine Paromomycin + Miltefosine 10% Charcoal in Sulfuric Acid (Option B) is administered topically for Cutaneous leishmaniasis not for visceral leishmaniasis. Glucocorticoids (Option C) : Glucocorticoids are not used to treat visceral leishmaniasis. They may be used in respiratory complications associated with cutaneous leishmaniasis. Pentamidine (Option D) : Pentamidine is used for certain infections but is not a first-line treatment for visceral leishmaniasis. It can be used for antimony resistant diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis. Reference: Paniker’s textbook of medical parasitology, 8th edition, Page 60,61, 62

questions.question: A 20-year-old female from Africa presents with hepatosplenomegaly, pallor, and generalised lymphadenopathy. Given her clinical features, there is a high suspicion of kala-azar. Which laboratory tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis? rk39 serological test Bone marrow aspirate Splenic aspirate Liver biopsy
questions.explanation: for the diagnosis of kala-azar. Diagnosis of Kala-azar : Depends upon direct and indirect evidences: CFT: complement fixation test; CIEP: counter immunoelectrophoresis; DAT: direct agglutination test; DNA: deoxyribonucleic acid; ELISA: enzyme linked immunosorbent assay; ICT: immunochromatographic test; IFAT: indirect immunofluorescent antibody test; LD: Leishman-Donovan; NNN: Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle; PCR: polymerase chain reaction; rK39: recombinant kinesin 39 Microscopy Demonstration of amastigotes in smears of tissue aspirates is the gold standard for diagnosis of kala-azar / VL Materials collected: Peripheral blood smear : Peripheral blood contains the amastigotes present inside circulating monocytes. It is best to examine buffy coat smear, Buffy coat smears show a diurnal periodicity, more smears being positive when collected during the day than at night. Blood smear test showing macrophages with amastigotes and extracellular Leishmania parasites (white arrows) Bone marrow aspirate : Generally, the sternal marrow is aspirated by puncturing the sternum at the level of the 2nd or 3rd intercostal space, using a sternal puncture needle. Bone marrow samples can also be obtained by puncturing the Iliac crest. Bone marrow aspirate showed Leishmania donovani bodies (LD bodies) in macrophages characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Fig. A and B). Splenic aspirate (most sensitive): Splenic aspirates are richer in parasites and, therefore, are more valuable for diagnosis. Splenic aspiration is contraindicated in patients with prolonged prothrombin time or if platelet count is less than 40,000/mm³ Lymph node aspirate : It is not useful in the diagnosis of Indian kala-azar Culture Media: NNN (Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle). Serodiagnosis Detection of antigen: ELISA and PCR Detection of antibody: rk39 test : A specific rapid immunochromatographic test (ICT) method for antibodies using a recombinant leishmanial antigen rk 39. The sensitivity of the test is 98% and specificity is 90%. Complement fixation test Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT) Counter immunoelectrophoresis (CIEP) ELISA and DOT-ELISA Direct agglutination test (DAT) Non-specific serum tests Napier aldehyde test Chopra's antimony test Skin test Leishmanin skin test- Montenegro test : Delayed hypersensitivity test. Positive result is indicated by induration and erythema of 5 mm or more after 48-72 hours . Positive result indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasites. questions.question: A 10-year-old male with a three-month history of fever, weight loss, fatigue, night sweats, and abdominal distention, along with splenomegaly, anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia, recently returned from rural India, where he was exposed to the vector given below. Clinical features of kala-azar: Onset: Insidious. The clinical illness begins with high-grade fever which may be remittent with twice daily spikes or intermittent or less commonly continuous. Night sweats Splenomegaly starts early and is progressive and massive. It is usually soft and nontender. Hepatomegaly is moderate. Lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic areas except the Indian subcontinent. Skin becomes dry, rough and darkly pigmented (hence, the name kala-azar). The hair becomes thin and brittle. Cachexia with marked anaemia, emaciation and weight loss is seen. Hematological abnormalities: Anemia is most always present and is usually severe leukopenia , thrombocytopenia is associated with epistaxis, gum bleeding, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. Ascites and edema may occur due to hypoalbuminemia. Renal involvement is also common. In the late stage of human

questions.question: What is the infective form of Leishmania donovani ?
questions.explanation: Infection of the Vector: A female sandfly (e.g., Phlebotomus , Lutzomyia ) bites an infected mammal and ingests blood containing amastigotes . Development in the Sandfly: Inside the sandfly’s midgut , amastigotes transform into promastigotes , which multiply and migrate to the proboscis. Transmission to the Mammalian Host: When the sandfly bites a new host, it injects the infective promastigotes . Transformation in the Host: Promastigotes are engulfed by macrophages and transform into amastigotes , which are non-flagellated and replicate intracellularly. Replication and Dissemination: Amastigotes multiply within macrophages, causing cell lysis and releasing new amastigotes to infect other macrophages. Transmission Back to the Sandfly: If an uninfected sandfly bites the infected host, it ingests amastigotes, and the cycle continues.

questions.question: Which organism does the following life cycle correspond to?
questions.explanation: stages: Trophozoite (or vegetative form) Cysts (or cystic form). Infective form: Mature cyst Transmission: Feco oral route. Habitat: Mucosa of duodenum and upper ileum. Ingesting a minimum of 10 cysts can cause an infection in a person. Within half an hour of ingestion, the cyst hatches out into two trophozoites, which multiply successively by binary fission and colonise the duodenum. During unfavorable condition , encystment occurs and cyst are passed in stool and remain viable in soil and water for several weeks. Life cycle : Host (only human) → Contaminated food and water (faeco-oral route) → Cyst (ingested form) → excystation occurs → Trophozoite. Diagnosis: Sample: Stool Microscopy: Cyst and trophozoite are seen. Trophozoite: 2 nuclei and four pairs of flagella with pear-shaped or tennis racket-shaped. Cyst: 1-4 nuclei and no flagella. questions.question: A 35-year-old woman with a travel history to South America presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, mild chest pain, and palpitations. She reports a history of fever, malaise, and swelling around her right eye 11 months ago, which resolved spontaneously. On examination, her heart rate is irregular, and she has mild cardiomegaly on chest X-ray. Which treatment options are most appropriate for her at this stage?
questions.explanation: parasite Trypanosoma cruzi . The history of fever and eyelid swelling points to a possible acute phase of the infection, while her current symptoms of fatigue, chest pain, palpitations, and cardiomegaly are typical complications of chronic Chagas disease. Benznidazole is one of the two mainstays of treatment for Chagas disease. It is effective in both the acute and chronic phases, particularly when cardiac symptoms are present. Early treatment can help reduce the risk of progression to severe cardiac disease and complications. The recommended treatment duration is typically 60 days. Nifurtimox (Option B) is another option for treating Chagas disease, but it is often associated with more significant side effects, including gastrointestinal issues and neurotoxicity. It is reserved for cases where benznidazole is contraindicated or not tolerated. Supportive care and monitoring (Option C) : While essential for managing symptoms and potential complications of Chagas disease (such as arrhythmias), this approach does not address the underlying infection. Antiarrhythmic medications only (Option D) can help manage the arrhythmias associated with Chagas-related cardiomyopathy, E.g., beta-blockers and digoxin. Supportive treatment such as pacemakers to manage arrhythmias and surgery for correction of megaesophagus and megacolon may be useful. Reference: Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 366, 367.

questions.question: Which of the following culture media is used to diagnose T. cruzi?
questions.explanation: growth of Trypanosoma cruzi in laboratory settings, making it crucial for its diagnosis. The diagnosis of Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, involves several methods. Clinical Evaluation Symptoms: Fever, fatigue, body aches, and chagoma (swelling at the infection site). Chronic symptoms affect the heart and digestive system. History of travel or residence in endemic areas. Serological Tests ELISA: Detects antibodies against T. cruzi. IHA: Measures antibodies in the blood. Western Blot: Confirms positive serological results. Microscopic Examination Blood smears can detect the trypomastigote form, especially during the acute phase. Giemsa or Wright’s stain enhances visibility. Culture Methods Yager’s LIT Medium: Cultures T. cruzi from blood or tissue samples, helpful in chronic cases. Molecular Methods PCR: Used for DNA detection. Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (Option A): This medium is primarily used for cultivating fungi and some bacteria. It is not suitable for growing Trypanosoma cruzi. Blood Agar (Option B): Blood agar is an enriched medium used for the cultivation of a wide variety of organisms, particularly fastidious bacteria. While it supports some protozoan growth, it is not specifically used for Trypanosoma cruzi diagnosis. MacConkey Agar (Option D): This medium is selective for Gram-negative bacteria and differentiates lactose fermenters from non-fermenters. It is not suitable for protozoan cultures like Trypanosoma cruzi. Reference: Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 366, 367.

questions.question: A 50-year-old man presents with persistent fatigue, chest pain, and difficulty breathing. He grew up in rural northern Argentina, where a childhood bug bite caused left eye swelling. Examination reveals leg swelling, an S3 gallop, and fatigue. IgG antibodies to Trypanosoma cruzi are detected by ELISA. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition? Cardiac manifestations are seen in 30% with chronic form of disease. Benznidazole is considered a drug of choice for the chronic form of disease. Chronic form of disease has cardiac and gastrointestinal involvement. Peripheral blood microscopy can be used to diagnose chronic disease. The acute form of disease presents with a generalised rash.
questions.explanation: Trypanosoma cruzi antibody detection in the peripheral blood is consistent with a chronic form of Chagas disease. Chagas disease is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, transmitted by triatomine bugs. Chagas’ disease occurs in four stages. 1. Early Stage Disease: It is characterised by cutaneous and ocular manifestations Chagoma : a painful subcutaneous nodule at the site of deposition of bug’s faeces, commonly seen on the face. Romana’s sign : It causes unilateral painless oedema of the eyelid and conjunctivitis. 2. Acute Chagas’ disease: About 1% of patients, progress to acute-stage disease, characterised by fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy (Statement 5) 3. Indeterminate stage: It is the asymptomatic phase; lasting for years to decades, before progressing into the symptomatic chronic stage 4. Chronic Chagas’ disease: The parasite multiples in the muscles (cardiac and GIT) and nervous tissue , producing various types of manifestations. Cardiac form: Occurs in 30% of the patients . The patient develops dilated cardiomyopathy, rhythm disturbances and thromboembolism. Gastrointestinal form: Megaesophagus and megacolon. Autoimmune hypothesis: T. cruzi antigens cross-react with mammalian antigens (molecular mimicry), producing autoantibodies that may be responsible for tissue injury seen in chronic Chagas’ disease Treatment of Chagas disease Therapy for Chagas’ disease is still unsatisfactory. In acute disease, Benznidazole is the drug of choice in Latin America. Nifurtimox or allopurinol is given alternatively. In chronic disease, these drugs lack efficacy and may cause many side effects. Supportive treatment, such as pacemakers to manage arrhythmias and surgery to correct megaesophagus and megacolon, may be useful (Statement 2) . In acute Chagas disease, the trypomastigotes are frequently found in peripheral blood, which can be detected by: Wet mount preparation Thick and thin smear examination. Antibody detection: Chronic Chagas disease is diagnosed by detecting specific IgG antibodies using ELISA, Western blot and Chagas RIPA (radioimmunoprecipitation assay) (Statement 4).

questions.question: Which organism does this life cycle belong to?
questions.explanation: involves several stages and hosts: Triatomine Bug (Vector Stage): The cycle begins when a triatomine bug ("kissing bug") feeds on the blood of a human. During this feeding, the bug defecates, and the faeces containing the infective stage (metacyclic trypomastigotes) are introduced into the wound or mucous membranes. Trypomastigote Stage: Once inside the host, the metacyclic trypomastigotes invade host cells and transform into intracellular amastigotes . In this stage, they multiply by binary fission. Amastigote Stage: Inside the host cells (particularly in muscle and nerve tissues), the amastigotes reproduce and eventually transform back into trypomastigotes, which then burst out of the cells and enter the bloodstream. Re-infection in the Vector: When another triatomine bug bites an infected host, it ingests the trypomastigotes present in the blood. Inside the bug, the trypomastigotes transform back into epimastigotes and multiply in the insect’s gut. Eventually, they differentiate into metacyclic trypomastigotes , ready to infect another host. In the Reduvid bug : Epimastigote and trypomastigote are seen. In adults : Amastigote and trypomastigote are seen. T. cruzi trypomastigotes in peripheral blood smear

questions.question: What is the drug of choice to treat Colpitis macularis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis?
questions.explanation: with Trichomoniasis. It is characterised by small punctate hemorrhagic spots on vaginal or cervical mucosa . Metronidazole or tinidazole is the drug of choice for Trichomonas vaginalis. Standard therapy: 2 g, single dose is usually effective. Both sexual partners must be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfection, especially asymptomatic males. Resistance to metronidazole is rare but reported (2.5-10%). If the standard therapy fails (with 5-day therapy), consider repeating the treatment course. Trichomoniasis can be prevented by: Treatment of both sexual partners. Safe sex practices like the use of condoms. Avoidance of sex with an infected person. Reference: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd edition, Page 773.

questions.question: A 28-year-old patient presents with watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and dehydration. A string test reveals a Giardia lamblia infection. After being treated with metronidazole, the patient does not fully respond, raising concerns about resistance. What would be the most appropriate next-line treatment?
questions.explanation: show resistance to metronidazole, leading to suboptimal treatment outcomes. In such cases, an alternative treatment option is tinidazole , which is effective against giardia and offers the advantage of being administered as a single dose. Treatment (DOC): Metronidazole Tinidazole (Single dose of 2g) Paromomycin (option B) is used to treat intestinal protozoan infection but is not the next-line treatment after metronidazole resistance. Doxycycline (option C) is an antibiotic commonly used for bacterial infections, but it is not a recommended treatment for giardia. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)(Option D): Antibiotic combination used for bacterial infection, not giardia. Reference: Paniker’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology 8 th Edition, Page 32.

questions.question: The microscopic examination of a wet mount preparation of stool from a patient with diarrhoea is shown below. Which organism is likely to exhibit this type of motility?
questions.explanation: characteristic of Giardia lamblia (trophozoite is motile with a slow oscillation along its axis, resembling a falling leaf). Types of motilities of microorganism: Motility Microorganism Darting motility Vibrio, Campylobacter Swarming motility Proteus Tumbling motility Listeria monocytogenes Stately motility Clostridia Corkscrew
